abstract.text: An object that uniquely identifies a record in a database.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A record ID object consists of a name string and a zone ID. The name string is an ASCII string that doesn’t exceed 255 characters in length. For automatically created records, the ID name string derives from a UUID and is, therefore, unique. When creating your own record ID objects, you can use names that have more meaning to your app or to the user, as long as each name is unique within the specified zone. For example, you might use a document name for the name string.

Record IDs must be unique within the specified database, but you can reuse record IDs in different databases. Each container has a public and a private database, and the private database is different for each unique user. This configuration provides for the reusing of record IDs in each user’s private database, but ensures that only one record uses a specific record ID in the public database.
CloudKit generally creates record IDs when it first saves a new record, but you might manually instantiate instances of
in  specific situations. For example, you must create an instance when saving a record in a zone other than the default zone. You also instantiate instances of
when retrieving specific records from a database.
Don’t subclass
After you create a
object, interactions with that object typically involve creating a new record or retrieving an existing record from a database.
You might also use record IDs when you can’t use a
object to refer to a record. References are only valid within a single zone of a database. To refer to objects outside of the current zone or database, save the strings in the record’s
and
objects. When you want to retrieve the record later, use those strings to recreate the record and zone ID objects so that you can fetch the record.

content.text: Creating Record IDs for New Records

inlineContent.text: To assign a custom record ID to a new record, you must create the
object first. You need to know the intended name and zone information for that record, which might also require creating a
object. After creating the record ID object, initialize your new record using its
method.

content.text: Using Record IDs to Fetch Records

inlineContent.text: Use a record ID to fetch the corresponding
object from a database quickly. You perform the fetch operation using a
object or the
method of the
class. In both cases, CloudKit returns the record asynchronously using the handler you provide.

abstract.text: Store structured app and user data in iCloud containers that all users of your app can share.
An object that represents a collection of record zones and subscriptions.
Fetches a specific record.
An operation for retrieving records from a database.
A collection of key-value pairs that store your app’s data.
An object that uniquely identifies a record in a database.
Creates a new record ID with the specified name in the default zone.
Creates a new record ID with the specified name and zone information.
The unique name of the record.
The ID of the zone that contains the record.
A relationship between two records in a record zone.
Possible values for record types of system records.
The time when CloudKit first saves the record to the server.
The ID of the user who creates the record.
Creates a record using an ID that you provide.
The ID of the user who most recently modified the record.
The most recent time that CloudKit saved the record to the server.
The server change token for the record.
The unique ID of the record.
The value that your app defines to identify the type of record.
The value that your app defines to identify the type of record.
Creates a new record ID with the specified name and zone information.
The name of a share record that manages a shared record zone.
An object that uniquely identifies a record zone in a database.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
